Consider the functions f(x,y)=\frac{ {{num1}} }{ {{denom1}} }, g(x,y)=\frac{ {{num2}} }{ {{denom2}} }. Determine whether each function is differentiable at the origin and prove it.
{{#firstdiff}}
f(x,y)=\frac{ {{num1}} }{ {{denom1}} } is differentiable.
Hint show that h_f(0,0)=f_x(0,0)x+f_y(0,0)y=0.
Then show that: \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{num1}} }{ \left({{denom1}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}} = \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{t11}} }{ \left({{denom1}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}} + \frac{ {{t12}} }{ \left({{denom1}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}} \leq \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{t11}} }{ x^{ {{n1}} } \sqrt{x^2}} + \frac{ {{t12}} }{ y^{ {{n1}} } \sqrt{y^2}}.
g(x,y)=\frac{ {{num2}} }{ {{denom2}} } is not differentiable.
Hint show that h_g(0,0)=g_x(0,0)x+g_y(0,0)y=0.
Then consider \lim_{(x,y)\to (0,0)} \frac{ {{num2}} }{ \left({{denom2}}\right) \sqrt{x^2+y^2}} along the lines x=0, y=0, y=x.
{{/firstdiff}}
